pages.text: Tyrannotitan chubutensis comes from the Early Cretaceous, with fossils found in the Cerro Barcino Formation, Argentina. It is a large carcharodontosaurid, growing up to 13 m in length, and 7 tons in body mass. It is the most basal of the giganotosaurinian tribe, and has unusual features, with a pneumatic hiatus at the anterior of its sacral region (Base of the tail),

which allowed the vertebral column to be pneumatised by independent segments of the respiratory system. The generic name derives from the Greek word 'Tyranno', to mean 'Tyrant'; and 'titan'. The specific name derives from the place name 'Chubut Province', near to were its fossils were found.
